channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Cameron Announces Response Plan to Beheading of British Aid Worker
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron said Britain would support American military action against the ISIS, but he did not commit his country to a more vigorous military role against the group.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JENNY ANDERSON and RUKMINI CALLIMACHI

item.title: Matthew Todd Miller Sentenced to 6 Years of Hard Labor in North Korea
item.description: The country’s official news agency offered few details of the one-day trial for Mr. Miller, who was convicted of committing “hostile acts” against the North after reportedly tearing up his tourist visa and demanding asylum.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Matthew Todd Miller is one of the three Americans known to be held in North Korea.

item.title: Arab Nations Offer to Conduct Airstrikes Against ISIS, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: The offer from several Arab countries was disclosed by American officials traveling with Secretary of State John Kerry, who is trying to mobilize international support against the militants.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Israeli Military Threatens to Discipline Veterans Involved in Protest Over Intelligence Activities
item.description: A group of veterans and reservists of a secretive military intelligence unit have declared they will not take part in surveillance activities against the Palestinians in the course of reserve duty.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Plan to Burn Waste Sets Off Protests in Southern China
item.description: Residents of a county in the province of Guangdong say they do not trust official reassurances about the environmental safety of a planned incinerator.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Kerry Scours Mideast for Aid in ISIS Fight
item.description: As Secretary of State John Kerry received broad assurances but no public commitments from Egypt as he tried to assemble a coalition to fight ISIS, Australia on Sunday committed aircraft and military advisers to the effort.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry and Sameh Shoukry, the Egyptian foreign minister, in Cairo.

item.title: ISIS Video Shows Execution of David Cawthorne Haines, British Aid Worker
item.description: A video released by the group shows the aid worker kneeling in a desert landscape that looks identical to where two American journalists were killed by the group in the past month. Moments later, he is beheaded.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: The Big Fix: Sun and Wind Alter Global Landscape, Leaving Utilities Behind
item.description: Electric utility executives all over the world are watching nervously as technologies they once dismissed as irrelevant begin to threaten their long-established business plans.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:credit: Djamila Grossman for The New York Times
item.media:description: New wind turbines off Germany, where renewable energy is soaring and driving down prices.

item.title: Malaysia Risks Enraging China by Inviting U.S. Spy Flights
item.description: Malaysia reportedly offered to allow P-8 Poseidon aircraft to fly out of the country’s most eastern area, a move that would give the United States greater proximity to the South China Sea.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Afghanistan Boldly Raises Its Colors, as Never Before
item.description: Flying from a specially erected pole more than 200 feet high, the black, red and green flag, at 97 feet by 65 feet, is big enough to drape over an intact Dreadnoughtus dinosaur fossil.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Afghan soldiers marched near the largest Afghan flag, a gift from India, after an inauguration ceremony Wednesday at Wazir Akbar Khan hill in Kabul.

item.title: North Korea Says Reports of Abuse Are Produced by Political ‘Racket’
item.description: The nation, condemned by a United Nations panel for gross human rights violations, issued its own report that made no mention of prison camps and claimed that individual freedoms were strong.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Back to the Slums of His Youth, to Defuse the Ebola Time Bomb
item.description: Liberia remains desperately short on everything needed to halt the spread of Ebola, but an epidemiologist is working block by block to fill a crucial need: the support of residents.
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Paths to War, Then and Now, Haunt Obama
item.description: Before recently announcing an escalated campaign against Islamic extremists, President Obama privately reflected on another time when a president weighed military action in the Middle East.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President Obama on Wednesday in Washington. Mr. Obama says he is aware of the “political price” he pays for being deliberate.

item.title: Oscar Pistorius Guilty of Culpable Homicide
item.description: Oscar Pistorius was found guilty of a charge equivalent to manslaughter in the shooting of Reeva Steenkamp, but he was granted bail and will remain free until sentencing procedures on Oct. 13.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius in court on Friday as he was convicted in the shooting death of his girlfriend.

item.title: In Jordan, Ever Younger Syrian Brides
item.description: For many Syrian families in Jordan’s refugee camps, marrying girls off at younger ages is seen as necessary, but women’s advocates say that they are trading immediate dangers for longer-term ones.
item.dc:creator: By RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: Uganda Fears Terror Attack After Finding Militant Cell
item.description: The Ugandan authorities have uncovered a “terrorist cell” run by the Somali militant Islamist group the Shabab, which they said they believed was planning an imminent attack.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Putin Intent on Taking ‘All of Ukraine,’ Premier Says
item.description: Only the military backing of NATO can defend Ukraine, the prime minister, Arseniy Yatsenyuk, told a conference of security experts in Kiev.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: The Donetsk International Airport on Saturday, as shelling continued between pro-Russian forces and the Ukrainian military.

item.title: Struggling to Starve ISIS of Oil Revenue, U.S. Seeks Assistance From Turkey
item.description: The territory ISIS controls in Iraq produces thousands of barrels of oil that can fetch millions on the Turkish black market, and U.S. officials are leaning heavily on Turkey to take action.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Close to Deal, Rebels Fight Yemeni Troops
item.description: Clashes broke out in a northwestern district of Sana near a state television building when troops stopped a rebel truck loaded with weapons, military officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Followers of the Houthi rebel group attended Friday prayers during a rally in Sana, the capital.

item.title: Air France-KLM Warns of Flight Cancellations as a Strike Looms
item.description: A dispute with pilots over the carrier’s planned expansion of a low-cost unit has the potential to disrupt the travel plans of tens of thousands of passengers.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Bracing for Change on Scotland’s Border, Whatever the Referendum Result
item.description: Polls show that the referendum on Scottish independence will be close, and people in England’s northernmost town fear that life will never be the same again — even if Scots vote to stay in the union.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Tourists posed for a photograph on the Scottish border in Berwick-Upon-Tweed, England, last weekend. Many of the city’s residents have Scottish roots.

item.title: Liberian President Pleads With Obama for Assistance in Combating Ebola
item.description: Liberia’s president, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, warned that without American assistance, the Ebola epidemic could send the country into the civil chaos that enveloped it for two decades.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: Muslim Brotherhood Says Qatar Ousted Its Members
item.description: Other Persian Gulf monarchies, mainly Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, have been putting pressure on Qatar to stop supporting the group.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Serge Schmemann: 13 Years After 9/11, the ‘War on Terror’ Has a New Focus
item.description: President Obama had little choice but to attack ISIS after its actions this year.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By SERGE SCHMEMANN

item.title: Obama Sees Iraq Resolution as a Legal Basis for Airstrikes, Official Says
item.description: The president has cited an earlier authorization by Congress as a basis for his campaign against ISIS.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE
